Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk valgrind
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: valgrind bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description: The valgrind packages provide the Valgrind programming tool that helps detect memory-management problems in programs. Valgrind is used for debugging memory, detecting memory leaks, and profiling. This update fixes the following bugs: Previously, Valgrind did not recognize various system calls on certain architectures. As a consequence, programs using these system calls on affected architectures generated a warning message when run under Valgrind. This update fixes recognizing of the following system calls: sendmmsg() and recvmmsg() on PowerPC and IBM S/390 (BZ#1192103) setuid() and setresgid() on the 64-bit ARM architecture (BZ#1251181) setgid() on the 64-bit ARM architecture (BZ#1188622) sigpending() on 64-bit IBM Power Systems (BZ#1225964) accept4() on 64-bit IBM Power Systems and the 64-bit ARM architecture (BZ#1190660) mount() and umount() on the 64-bit ARM architecture (BZ#1193796) mbind(), get_mempolicy(), set_mempolicy(), flock(), msgget(), msgctl(), msgrcv(), and msgsnd() on the 64-bit ARM architecture (BZ#1188623) The Valgrind memcheck tool did not recognize certain instruction patterns to perform conditional branches on IBM System z. As a consequence, a program using an instruction sequence of "tg" + "jl" (jump if Valgrind was unable to emulate the IBM System z fiebra instruction. Consequently, programs using the fiebra instruction could terminate unexpectedly when run under Valgrind. With this update, Valgrind correctly recognizes the IBM System z fiebra instruction, and the described problem no longer occurs. (BZ#1181993) Previously, Valgrind did not properly handle the AT_DCACHESIZE and AT_HWCAP2 auxiliary vector entries when used on 64-bit IBM Power Systems. Consequently, programs that depend on the values of AT_DCACHESIZE or AT_HWCAP2 (for example, to determine the hardware capabilities of this architecture) were unable to run correctly under Valgrind. With this update, Valgrind handles both auxiliary vector entries correctly and passes the values through to the program running under Valgrind. As a result, programs that depend on those entries, such as qemu-kvm, now run correctly under Valgrind. (BZ#1249381) Note that Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.2 supports only the Open MPI application binary interface (ABI) in version 1.10, which is incompatible with the previously shipped 1.6 version of the Open MPI ABI. As a consequence, programs that are built against the earlier version of Open MPI cannot be run under Valgrind included in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.2. Use the Red Hat Developer Toolset version of Valgrind for programs linked against Open MPI version 1.6. (BZ#1258841) Users of valgrind are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
